data.description: Charles Pinckney was a principal author and signer of the United States Constitution and went on to be a political leader in South Carolina for over 40 years. The park preserves Snee Farm, one of his plantation properties, where visitors can learn about the politician's influences on Charleston, the African people he enslaved, plantation operations, and the legacy of Pinckney's life.
data.directionsInfo: The park is located on the south side of Long Point Road .7 miles from US Highway 17, or 3 miles if coming from I-526.

operatingHours.description:
The historic home (Visitor Center) is open seasonally. For the 2025 season, the Visitor Center will be open three days a week Friday through Sunday from 9:00 a.m. until 4:30 p.m.. The season begins on Friday, May 2, 2025 and ends on Sunday, September 28, 2025.  

Park grounds are open Wednesday - Sunday, 9:00 AM - 5:00 PM. 

The entrance gate to the parking lot will be locked when the grounds are closed.
operatingHours.name: Charles Pinckney National Historic Site

images.title: Historic House and Grounds
images.altText: 1828 Lowcountry cottage and grounds
images.caption: The historic house serves as the park's visitor center and features exhibits, film options, and a museum shop.

images.credit: New York State Office of Parks, Recreation and Historic Preservation
images.title: Charles Pinckney
images.altText: Charles Pinckney portrait
images.caption: American founding father, Charles Pinckney, was a contributing author and signer of the U.S. Constitution.

images.title: Live Oak
images.altText: Live Oak
images.caption: Spanish Moss drape Live Oak in the early morning sun.

images.title: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.altText: Southern Magnolia (Magnolia grandiflora)
images.caption: Flowering plants, like this Southern Magnolia, are remnant of historic ornamental gardens once enjoyed by former farm owners and still marveled over by modern visitors.

images.title: Corn Crib
images.altText: Corn Crib
images.caption: Snee Farm, once owned by Charles Pinckney, was a working farm for over 200 years. This corn crib, built in 1910, is one of the few remaining structures of a bygone era.

images.title: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.altText: Boardwalk and Marsh
images.caption: A .25 mile loop trail is a popular activity for visitors to enjoy the grounds and see points of cultural and natural interest along the way.

data.weatherInfo: Winters are generally mild. Summers are hot and humid.
data.name: Charles Pinckney

data.description: Astonishing biodiversity exists in Congaree National Park, the largest intact expanse of old growth bottomland hardwood forest remaining in the southeastern United States. Waters from the Congaree and Wateree Rivers sweep through the floodplain, carrying nutrients and sediments that nourish and rejuvenate this ecosystem and support the growth of national and state champion trees.
data.directionsInfo: From Interstate 77, Exit 5 At Exit 5 turn onto SC Hwy 48 East/Bluff Road. Following the brown and white "Congaree National Park" directional signs, travel approximately 8 miles on and then take a slight right onto Old Bluff Road. Follow Old Bluff Road for 4.5 miles to the park entrance sign, which will be on the right. Proceed one mile to the Harry Hampton Visitor Center. Parking lots will be on the right.

operatingHours.description:
Congaree National Park is generally open 24 hours a day year-round. For visitor and staff safety, park operations and/or weather conditions may occasionally result in short term, temporary closures. Please review the park webpage and social media platforms for more information. 

The Harry Hampton Visitor Center is open 9-5, daily. It is closed New Year's Day, President's Day, Columbus Day, Thanksgiving, and Christmas Day. Please check alerts prior to your visit.
operatingHours.name: Congaree Operating Hours (Not Visitor Center Hours)

images.title: Congaree River
images.altText: View of the Congaree River during the Fall
images.caption: View of the Congaree River during the Fall

data.weatherInfo: Check the forecast before getting on the road. Conditions can change rapidly within the park. Flooding can happen with little or no warning, so make sure to check water levels for Cedar Creek and the Congaree River.
data.name: Congaree

data.description: A pasturing area at the time of the battle, this Revolutionary War site commemorates the place where Daniel Morgan and his army turned the flanks of Banastre Tarleton's British army. This classic military tactic, known as a double envelopment, secured a patriot victory.
data.directionsInfo: From I-85 S, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right. From I-85 N, take exit 92, turn right toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx.10 miles on the left. From I-26 E, take exit 5, turn left toward Chesnee on Hwy 11, approx. 20 miles on the right. From I-26 W, take I-85 North, take exit 83. Turn left on Hwy 110, approx. 8 miles. Turn right on Hwy 11. The park is about a half mile on the right.

operatingHours.description:
The visitor center parking lot is open 9:00 am - 5:00 pm. The front gate closes at 5:00 pm. Loop Road closes at 4:30 pm. After hours parking is located 1 mile east at the intersection of Hwy 11 and Hayes Road and is open dawn to dusk.

Visitor Center is open Wed - Sunday 9 - 5.
operatingHours.name: Grounds

data.name: Cowpens

data.fullName: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie National Historical Park
data.description: Two forts stand at the entrance of Charleston Harbor. Patriots inside a palmetto log fort, later named Fort Moultrie, defeated the Royal Navy in 1776. As Charleston blazed a path towards secession to preserve slavery, construction on a new fort, Fort Sumter, proceeded. The Confederacy fired on the US garrison of Fort Sumter on April 12, 1861 opening the Civil War, which redefined American freedom.

entranceFees.description: Fort Moultrie charges a per person entrance fee for adults. Anyone 16 years old or older is considered an adult.
entranceFees.title: Entrance - Per Person

entrancePasses.description: The Fort Moultrie Annual Park Pass provides entry into Fort Moultrie for the pass holder and 3 other adults.  The pass is valid for a year from the date of purchase.  Each Fort Moultrie Annual Park Pass may have 2 separate passholders.
entrancePasses.title: Annual Entrance - Park

data.directionsInfo: Fort Sumter is accessible by ferry boat. Boats depart at scheduled times from two sites. The primary departure point is the Fort Sumter Visitor Center, 340 Concord Street, Charleston. Boats also depart from Patriots Point, 40 Patriots Point Boulevard, Mount Pleasant. There is a fee for the concession-operated ferry. Fort Moultrie is accessible by car at 1214 Middle Street, Sullivan's Island. A park entrance fee is charged for the park. Details at: https://www.nps.gov/fosu/planyourvisit/directions.

operatingHours.description: Fort Moultrie represents the entire history of static seacoast defenses in the United States, from the American Revolution through World War II. The site includes a visitor center with museum exhibits. The Fort Moultrie Visitor Center is open daily 9:00 am-4:30 pm. The fort itself is open until 4:30 pm all year. There is an entrance fee for the park.
operatingHours.name: Fort Moultrie

operatingHours.description: The Fort Sumter Visitor Center at Liberty Square, 340 Concord Street, Charleston, is the primary departure point for ferry boats to Fort Sumter. This visitor education center is free. There is a fee for the concession-operated ferry to Fort Sumter.
operatingHours.name: Fort Sumter Visitor Center at Liberty Square

images.title: Fort Moultrie
images.altText: A row of cannon with Fort Moultrie in the background. A US flag is flying in the fort.
images.caption: Fort Moultrie spans 171 years from 1776-1947

images.title: Fort Sumter
images.altText: Fort Sumter with a US flag flying above the fort with dock in the foreground
images.caption: Fort Sumter is located on an island in Charleston Harbor and is only accessible by boat.

images.title: Fort Sumter Cannon

images.caption: Fort Sumter cannon sitting on cannon carriage under a brick casemate

images.title: Inside Fort Moultrie Today
images.altText: Center of image is round metal and glass signal light with grassy hills hills in background
images.caption: Interior View of Fort Moultrie featuring the World War II signal light with grass hills and black concrete gun bateries

images.title: Fort Sumter Visitor Center
images.altText: A three-story brick structure with a staircase in front and water in the background
images.caption: The Fort Sumter Visitor Center is the primary departure point for the ferries to Fort Sumter.

data.weatherInfo: Mild winters. Hot and humid during the summer.
data.name: Fort Sumter and Fort Moultrie

data.description: Thomas Jefferson called it "The turn of the tide of success." The battle of Kings Mountain, fought October 7th, 1780, was an important American victory during the Revolutionary War. The battle was the first major patriot victory to occur after the British invasion of Charleston, SC in May 1780. The park preserves the site of this important battle.
data.directionsInfo: Kings Mountain National Military Park is located on South Carolina Highway 216. From Greenville, SC travel on I-85 North to NC Exit #2. Turn right onto Hwy 216. From Charlotte, NC travel on I- 85 South to NC Exit #2. Turn left onto Hwy 216.

operatingHours.description:
Park Grounds (Restrooms, Parking Lot and Trails) Open Daily 9:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.

Visitor Center Open Wednesday - Sunday 9 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.
operatingHours.name: Kings Mountain National Military Park

data.name: Kings Mountain

data.description: Settlers struggled against the harsh backcountry to survive. Cherokee Indians hunted and fought to keep their land. Two towns and a trading post were formed then abandoned to the elements. And two Revolutionary War battles claimed over 100 lives. Come discover the 18th century history of South Carolina.
data.directionsInfo: 2 miles south of Ninety Six, SC on Hwy 248. For more detailed information, click on "Directions Details" below.

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open from sunrise to sunset. There are eight parking spots located outside of the front gate for early and late visitors.
operatingHours.name: Park Grounds

operatingHours.description:
From April1, to October 31, the Star Fort Pond is open for fishing on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays.

The Pond is CLOSED Sundays through Tuesdays, Thursdays, and from November 1through March 31.

From April through October there is a portalet located in the Pond parking lot.
operatingHours.name: Star Fort Pond

data.description: Stretching 330-miles through four states (Virginia, Tennessee, North and South Carolina) the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail traces the route used by Patriot militia during the pivotal Kings Mountain campaign of 1780. Follow their campaign by utilizing a Commemorative Motor Route along existing state highways marked with the distinctive trail logo, or 80+ miles of walkable trail.
data.directionsInfo: The trail travels over 330 miles through four states.

operatingHours.description:
The Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail can be visited in any season.
It includes sections of walkable pathway, a Commemorative Motor Route, affiliated historic sites and museums, and wayside exhibits.
Along the way it passes through four NPS areas, two National Forests, an Army Corps of Engineers Dam &Reservoir, plus several state and county parks.
operatingHours.name: Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail

images.title: Cherokee Ford Trail in Gaffney, SC
images.altText: A dirt trail winds along in a forest.
images.caption: Hiking sections of the Overmountain Victory Trail is a favorite pastime.

images.title: Sycamore Shoals in Elizabethton, TN
images.altText: A large group of living historians stand in a river and fire muskets, with a cloud of smoke rising.
images.caption: Living historians bring the Overmountain Victory Trail to life.

images.title: Alexander's Ford Trail at Bradley Nature Preserve
images.altText: A cut log is laying over a crevasse on a trail in the woods.
images.caption: Great hiking adventure awaits on sections of the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail.

images.title: Hampton Creek Cove Trail at Yellow Mountain Gap
images.altText: 5 people are hiking along a trail surrounded by mountains and wildflowers and trees.
images.caption: Hikers enjoy exploring sections of the Overmountain Victory National Historic Trail.

images.title: Yadkin River Greenway in Wilkesboro, NC
images.altText: A walking bridge with trees in the background.
images.caption: Hikers can enjoy walking over many bridges along the trail.

data.weatherInfo: Temperatures for the area range from very hot and humid in the summer to cool and moderate in the winter.
data.name: Overmountain Victory

data.description: The Reconstruction era,1861-1900 the historic period in which the United States grappled with the question of how to integrate millions of newly freed African Americans into social, political, economic, and labor systems, was a time of significant transformation. The people, places, and events in Beaufort County, South Carolina, reflect on the most important issues of this tumultuous time period.
data.directionsInfo: The park's headquarters is located at 706 Craven Street in Beaufort, South Carolina, directly across the street from the Beaufort Visitor Center in the Beaufort Arsenal, and next door to the downtown Beaufort Public Library.

operatingHours.description: The park grounds are open daily from sunrise to sunset. In addition, the park maintains several visitor centers and contact stations throughout the region.
operatingHours.name: Park Hours

images.title: Brick Baptist Church
images.altText: A two story brick building flanked by large live oak trees
images.caption: Brick Baptist Church, located on the Penn Center National Historic Landmark District, was home to the Penn School between 1862-1865

images.title: The Old Beaufort Fire House
images.altText: A one story brick building with large arched windows
images.caption: The Old Beaufort Firehouse, located in downtown Beaufort, serves as the park headquarters and visitor center

images.title: A Ranger Guided Tour at Brick Church
images.altText: A park ranger holds a sign while talking to young people.
images.caption: Ranger guided tours and programs are a great way to explore Reconstruction Era National Historical Park

images.title: Camp Saxton
images.altText: A Park Ranger points at the ruins of a tabby wall with three people looking on
images.caption: Camp Saxton it partly located on SCDNR and US Navy Property. It was here that Black soldiers during the Civil War took their first steps towards citizenship.

images.title: Darrah Hall
images.altText: A crowd of people stand in front of a large white wooden building
images.caption: Darrah Hall is the oldest building on the campus of the Penn Center, and serves as the base of operations for the park in the Penn Center National Historic Landmark District

images.title: The Penn Center
images.altText: A large crowd of people gather in a field. In the foreground is an NPS sign
images.caption: The Penn Center is one of the park's partners to help preserve and tell the story of education during the Reconstruction Era

data.weatherInfo: Winters can be mild, with periods of cold weather. During the Spring and Fall, weather is typically nice, with highs in the 70s and 80s. Summers can be very hot, with high temperatures and high humidity. Located in a coastal region, the park is susceptible to hurricanes during the Summer and Fall.
data.name: Reconstruction Era
